title: Avoiding Compliments and Fluff
summary: Steer clear of vague praise or non-specific feedback to ensure honest and actionable conversations.

details.content: Compliments and fluff can make conversations feel polite but unhelpful, masking real opinions and preventing you from learning the truth.
Instead of saying, 'That sounds like a great idea!', ask, 'When was the last time you tried to solve this problem?'

content: Notice when you or the other person uses vague praise.
Redirect the conversation to specifics.
Politely ignore compliments and dig deeper.

title: Asking About Specifics in the Past
summary: Focus on what people have actually done, not what they say they might do.

details.content: People are bad at predicting their own future behavior. Past actions are the best indicator of real needs and habits.
Ask, 'Can you tell me about the last time you encountered this problem?' instead of 'Would you use a product like this?'

content: Frame questions around real events and actions.
Avoid hypothetical or future-focused questions.
Listen for concrete stories and timelines.

title: Understanding Customer's Life Context
summary: Learn about the broader context of your customer's life to understand their motivations and constraints.

details.content: Understanding context helps you see where your idea fits and what obstacles or priorities your customer faces.
Ask, 'Walk me through your typical day at work,' to uncover routines, pain points, and decision-making processes.

content: Ask open-ended questions about routines and challenges.
Listen for underlying motivations and constraints.
Map out the customer's workflow or environment.

title: Listening More Than Talking
summary: Let the customer do most of the talking to uncover genuine insights.

details.content: Talking too much can bias the conversation and prevent you from hearing the customer's real thoughts and experiences.
After asking a question, pause and let silence encourage the other person to elaborate.

content: Aim for the customer to speak at least 70% of the time.
Use active listening techniques (nodding, summarizing).
Resist the urge to fill silences or jump in with your own ideas.

title: Avoiding Pitching Your Idea
summary: Refrain from selling your solution during customer conversations; focus on learning instead.

details.content: Pitching can bias feedback and make people tell you what you want to hear, rather than the truth.
Instead of describing your product, ask about the customer's current solutions and frustrations.

content: Keep your idea out of the conversation as long as possible.
If asked, give only a brief, non-leading description.
Refocus on the customer's experiences and needs.

title: Seeking Disconfirming Evidence
summary: Actively look for information that could prove your assumptions wrong.

details.content: Confirmation bias can lead you to ignore warning signs and build something nobody wants.
Ask, 'What would make this solution not work for you?' or 'Have you tried something similar that failed?'

content: Challenge your own assumptions in every conversation.
Invite criticism and negative feedback.
Document and reflect on evidence that contradicts your beliefs.

title: Focusing on Problems, Not Solutions
summary: Concentrate on understanding the customer's real problems before discussing possible solutions.

details.content: Jumping to solutions too soon can cause you to miss the real issues or build the wrong thing.
Ask, 'What’s the hardest part about doing this task?' rather than 'Would you use a tool that does X?'

content: Start every conversation by exploring pain points.
Delay discussing features or solutions until you fully understand the problem.
Summarize the problem in the customer's own words before moving forward.
